p.s: Another claim of John Worne is that language learning is whatever the UK's future prosperity and global standing.

First of all I don't agree with his examples given on problems English speakers without foreign language skills have abroad (cf. ll. 13ff.) as they are very rare scenarios on are not of interest in the context of global economy.
But apart from that I agree with John Worne that language skills are defenitelydefinitely needed in a globalised world for the UK's economy.
Worne proves that with the fact that almost two-thirds of UK businesses need foreign language skills (ll. 19f.).

Like it is important for countries around the world to learn English to enter the global market and adapt to Western developments it is for the British to have foreign language speaking abilities so they can gain knowledge about the rising markets in for example Brasil, India or China where adaptation to the local needs and proferations is needed.
Because the UK can't just rely on the others to adapt to them in order for them to maintain a primary position in the global standing.
And also prosperity can gained by the access to foreign markets.

So considering als points I would agree to John Worne statement and see a great opportunity in foreign language skills for Brits that I believe that new progress by offerings of universities is a good development.
